title: Kretania martini
text:
Kretania martini, or Martin's blue"," is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a>n <a href="butterfly">butterfly</a> in the <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Lycaenidae">Lycaenidae</a> and the <a href="subfamily">subfamily</a> <a href="Polyommatinae">Polyommatinae</a>.
Systematics.
The species was <a href="Species%20description">first described</a> by French entomologist <a href="Gaston%20Allard">Gaston Allard</a> in 1867. He initially named the species "Lycaena martini". The <a href="Type%20%28biology%29">type specimen</a> was from <a href="Lambaesis">Lambaesis</a>, in <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>.
The species was placed in the <a href="genus">genus</a> "<a href="Plebejus">Plebejus</a>", and the <a href="subgenus">subgenus</a> "Plebejides," but was later moved to the genus "<a href="Kretania">Kretania</a>", along with other species placed in "Plebejides".
Subspecies.
Several <a href="subspecies">subspecies</a> have been described.
Description.
The <a href="imago">imago</a> of the species is a small butterfly which is <a href="sexually%20dimorphic">sexually dimorphic</a>. The top of the male is blue purple with a thin black border and a white fringe, while that of the female is dark brown with a blue basal suffusion, white fringe, and a series of orange submarginal half moons and black marginal spots on the hindwings.
The underside of the wings is beige gray decorated with black spots circled in white, with a series of orange submarginal half moons bordered by black and white chevrons, and a series of black marginal spots.
The ornamentation resembles a similar species, "<a href="Kretania%20allardii">Kretania allardii</a>".
Biology.
Phenology.
The species emerges from May to late June.
Host plants.
Plants that host the species include "<a href="Astragalus%20tragacantha">Astragalus massiliensis</a>" and "<a href="Acanthyllis%20numidia">Acanthyllis numidia</a>" for "K. m. martini", "<a href="Astragalus%20incanus%20incurvus">Astragalus incanus incurvus</a>" for "K. m. ungemachi" and "<a href="Astragalus%20armatus">Astragalus armatus</a>" for "K. m. regularis". "<a href="Astragalus%20alopecuroides">Astragalus alopecuroides</a>" and "<a href="Astragalus%20nemorosus">Astragalus nemorosus</a>" also host the species. The caterpillars exist in <a href="myrmecophily">myrmecophily</a> with ants from the genus "<a href="Crematogaster">Crematogaster</a>."
Distribution.
The species is present in Northern Africa, specifically Morocco and in northern Algeria.
It prefers fairly dry and flowery open environments, generally between 1,000 and 2,100 m above sea level.
Conservation.
In Morocco, the subspecies "Kretania martini ungemachi" is considered vulnerable, and the subspecies "K. m. regularis" and "K. m. mgouna" endangered.
